articles.headline: With ‘Spygate,’ Trump Shows How He Uses Conspiracy Theories to Erode Trust
articles.snippet: The president’s promotion of the unconfirmed claims he calls “Spygate” continues a long history of presidential trafficking in tales of shadowy cabals and secret plots.
articles.abstract: The president’s promotion of the unconfirmed claims he calls “Spygate” continues a long history of presidential trafficking in tales of shadowy cabals and secret plots.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As a candidate, Donald J. Trump claimed that the United States government had known in advance about the Sept. 11 attacks. He hinted that Antonin Scalia, a Supreme Court justice who died in his sleep two years ago, had been murdered. And for years, Mr. Trump pushed the notion that President Barack Obama had been born in Kenya rather than Honolulu, making him ineligible for the presidency.
articles.byline: By Julie Hirschfeld Davis and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: Why Starbucks’s Bias Training, Despite Skepticism, Is an Important Start
articles.snippet: Starbucks is under fire for temporarily shutting 8,000 stores on Tuesday to train employees about bias. The effort won’t solve the problem, but it’s a good start.
articles.abstract: Starbucks is under fire for temporarily shutting 8,000 stores on Tuesday to train employees about bias. The effort won’t solve the problem, but it’s a good start.
articles.lead_paragraph: Starbucks will temporarily shut 8,000 stores for four hours Tuesday afternoon to conduct racial bias training for its employees. It follows an incident in Philadelphia last month in which two black men were arrested simply for waiting in a store.

articles.headline: ‘Diamonds Are Forever,’ and Made by Machine
articles.snippet: De Beers is getting into the lab-created diamond business with a new line of fashion jewelry and an aggressive pricing strategy.
articles.abstract: De Beers is getting into the lab-created diamond business with a new line of fashion jewelry and an aggressive pricing strategy.
articles.lead_paragraph: OXFORDSHIRE, England — In a white industrial building in the rolling hills of the English countryside 16 miles from Oxford, silver machines shaped like spaceships hum inside vast laboratories. They are replicating the extreme pressure and temperatures found deep in the earth’s crust and producing, in mere weeks, what historically nature managed only over billions of years: flawless diamonds.
articles.byline: By Elizabeth Paton and Vanessa Friedman

articles.headline: Stacey Abrams Didn’t Play It Safe. Neither Do These Female Candidates.
articles.snippet: As women run for Congress and state offices this year, they want to campaign and win on their own terms. Some are coming for their own party. And many are not willing to wait.
articles.abstract: As women run for Congress and state offices this year, they want to campaign and win on their own terms. Some are coming for their own party. And many are not willing to wait.
articles.lead_paragraph: The question went out late one night on a private message chain of insurgent female candidates for Congress: Do you really attack a fellow Democrat?
articles.byline: By Susan Chira and Matt Flegenheimer

articles.headline: Trump, Stung by Being Attacked as Soft on China, Pushes Ahead on Tariffs
articles.snippet: In a reversal, the administration said it would impose tariffs and other measures in the coming weeks, ramping up pressure on China to make trade concessions.
articles.abstract: In a reversal, the administration said it would impose tariffs and other measures in the coming weeks, ramping up pressure on China to make trade concessions.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump, stung by criticism that he has gone soft on China and less worried about Beijing’s ability to disrupt a potential summit meeting with North Korea, reversed course on Tuesday and declared that the United States would impose tariffs and other punitive measures on China.
articles.byline: By Mark Landler and Ana Swanson

articles.headline: After Racist Tweet, Roseanne Barr’s Show Is Canceled by ABC
articles.snippet: Ms. Barr cited “The Planet of the Apes” in discussing Valerie Jarrett, a black woman and former adviser to President Barack Obama. ABC Entertainment’s president called it “abhorrent.”
articles.abstract: Ms. Barr cited “The Planet of the Apes” in discussing Valerie Jarrett, a black woman and former adviser to President Barack Obama. ABC Entertainment’s president called it “abhorrent.”
articles.lead_paragraph: Two months ago, Roseanne Barr was a star again.
